[[File:SBP 6196.jpg|thumb|Students working in a Mantle of the Expert context as a team of park rangers performing an operation on an injured animal.]] '''Mantle of the Expert''' is an education approach that uses imaginary contexts to generate purposeful<ref>Taylor, T. (2016) A Beginner's Guide to Mantle of the Expert. Singular. p.51.(Due for publication July 2016)</ref> and engaging<ref>Taylor, T. (2016) p.13.</ref> activities for learning. Within the fiction the students are cast as a team of experts working for a client on a commission. The commission is designed by the teacher to generate tasks and activities that fulfil the requirements of the client as well as create opportunities for students to study wide areas of the curriculum. For example, a class of students are cast (within the fiction) as a team of [[archaeologists]] [[excavation (archaeology)|excavating]] an Egyptian tomb for the [[Cairo Museum]]. To complete the commission they research ancient Egyptian history – learning about tombs, artefacts, and rituals – and in the process study history, geography, art, design and other subjects, as well as develop their skills in reading, writing, problem solving, and inquiry. Mantle of the Expert is not designed to teach the entire curriculum, all the time, but is rather an approach to be used selectively by the teacher along with a range of other methods.
Mantle of the Expert was developed by [[Dorothy Heathcote]] at [[Newcastle University]] in the 1970s and 80's. An internationally renowned authority<ref>Wagner, B.J. (1976) Dorothy Heathcote: Drama as a Learning Medium. London: Trentham Books.</ref> on drama for learning,<ref>Bolton, G. (2003) Dorothy Heathcote's Story: the biography of a remarkable drama teacher. London: Trentham Books, introduction p.x</ref> Heathcote's aim was to provide non-drama specialists with an approach that would support them in using drama across the [[curriculum]].<ref>Bolton (2003) p.126.</ref> Heathcote believed drama was an underused approach outside drama studios and could be used as a powerful medium for learning across the curriculum.<ref>Bolton (2003) p.126.</ref>
== Origins ==
Heathcote said she didn't as much invent Mantle of the Expert as "find herself doing it."<ref>Bolton (2003) p.127.</ref> In an interview with [[Sandra Hesten]] in 1993, Heathcote recounts working with a small group of children on a drama context about the [[Nativity of Jesus|Nativity]] – "…thinking about it later I thought that's really important – they were expert kings. And then it began to dawn on me. People had to have a [[point of view (philosophy)|point of view]]. So when I reviewed the week I thought – the point of view of inn-keeping, the point of view of soldiers who are working for [[Ancient Rome|Rome]], the point of view of [[angels]], the point of view of kings. And that's when it started coming together."<ref>Hesten, S. (1986) The Heathcote Archive. PhD thesis. p.156.</ref>
This conversation is recorded by Hesten in her [[PhD thesis]] and is recounted by Heathcote at least two further times, once in the documentary "Pieces of Dorothy" and in an interview for the Mantle of the Expert website in 2009 - "That was the start, I then started to think, what do I call it? That's when I got this crazy name. Which is extreme not crazy, just fanciful. I can't find a better name." Although Heathcote doesn't put a date on the 'Nativity' context in any of these interviews, it was likely to be around the mid-1970s, since soon after this time she began talking about Mantle of the Expert as a distinct approach and incorporated it into her courses at Newcastle University.<ref>Hesten, S. (1986).</ref>
Working with her graduate students at Newcastle University, Heathcote spent much of the late 1970s and 80's researching, developing, and evaluating Mantle of the Expert across a range of settings – [[Primary school|primary]] and [[secondary school]]s, [[Special school|special schools]], [[Borstal|borstals]], and adult and child [[mental hospital]]s.<ref>Bolton (2003) p.125.</ref> Her method was to teach week long sessions, planned in advance with her students, which involved them playing different roles in the classroom. Although often involving a great deal of improvisation and discussion, Heathcote's Mantle of the Expert contexts were carefully planned and often elaborately embellished with resources, props, and costumes created by the graduate students. Essentially experimental in nature, these sessions were discussed, analysed, and evaluated by Heathcote and her students, and formed the foundations for the student's studies of the approach. In some cases these 'experiments' were documented.<ref>Hesten, S. (1986) p. 217.</ref>
After retiring in 1987, Heathcote continued to work on Mantle of the Expert, and used the approach in various settings and in different parts of the world.
In 1995 she co-wrote, "Drama for Learning: Dorothy Heathcote's Mantle of the Expert Approach to Education" with Gavin Bolton.<ref>Heathcote, D. and Bolton, G. (1995) Drama for Learning: Dorothy Heathcote's Mantle of the Expert Approach to Education. Portsmouth: Heinemann.</ref>
== Later Developments ==
Among her students in the early 1980s was Luke Abbott. Abbott was a secondary school drama teacher at the time and took a year out to study with Heathcote on her graduate drama course. After completing his M.A. Abbott switched jobs and became a Local Authority advisor for Essex County Council and began working in schools – both primary and secondary – across the region.<ref>{{cite web|title=Articles|url=http://www.mantleoftheexpert.com/about-moe/articles/|website=Mantle of the Expert|date=25 March 2008}}</ref>
In this new role Abbott used Mantle of the Expert with teachers in their classrooms, using Heathcote's laboratory method. His aim was to demonstrate how Mantle of the Expert worked with students in authentic classroom settings, using few props or elaborate resources. His approach was more pragmatic than Heathcote's and designed to be easier for teachers to implement.
In the early 2000s Abbott organised a series of conferences, both nationally and internationally, to promote the approach and its use as a pedagogy. With Heathcote as the keynote speaker and classroom teachers running workshops, Abbott's aim was to demystify Mantle of the Expert and turn the approach into something non-specialist drama teachers could use across the curriculum (as Heathcote had always planned). Schools such as Bealings Primary in Suffolk, Pound Lane Infants in Sussex, and Recreation Road Infants in Norwich began to use Mantle of the Expert as their main teaching approach and gained 'outstanding' grades from [[Ofsted]], as well as excellent [[National Curriculum assessment|SATs]] results.
Since this time, Abbott and others have continued to develop Mantle of the Expert, working to train teachers in the UK, New Zealand, USA, and Palestine. Since 2012 eight schools in different regions of England have become '[http://www.mantleoftheexpert.com/training/mantle-of-the-expert-quality-mark-training-schools/ training schools]' for Mantle of the Expert. And the approach is included in several university teacher training courses (including Newcastle).
== Method ==
[[File:SBP 6352.jpg|thumb|Using Heathcote's drama conventions, students explore why so many male passengers died during the sinking of the Titanic.]] Mantle of the Expert works<ref>Taylor, T. (2016) p.25</ref> by the teacher planning a fictional context where the students take on the responsibilities of an expert team. As the team, they are commissioned by a client (within the fiction) to work on a commission, which has been planned by the teacher to generate tasks and activities that involve them in studying and developing wide areas of the curriculum.<ref>Taylor, T. (2016)</ref>
From the beginning the students are aware that they are involved in a fiction. Mantle of the Expert is not a simulation invented by the teacher to trick them into thinking they are involved in something real.<ref>Taylor, T. (2016) p.13.</ref>
Consciously going in and coming out of the fiction is an important dimension of the Mantle of the Expert approach. Like imaginative play<ref>Taylor, T. (2016) p.13.</ref> the participants are always aware that the fiction is something that can stop and start as and when they or the teacher decide. In this way, an activity inside the fiction can create a purpose for curriculum learning outside the fiction. The teacher can introduce the task to the students 'as if' they are the expert team, such as writing a report to the museum, and then stop the story and come out of the fiction to teach them directly the knowledge and skills they need to complete the task. Once the task is complete, the teacher can restart the story and the students can see how their work has an effect inside the fiction. It is this process of going in and coming out of the fictional context that defines Mantle of the Expert as a teaching and learning approach.<ref>Taylor, T. (2016) p.13.</ref>
The 'mantle' in Mantle of the Expert is a metaphor.<ref>Taylor, T. (2016) p.53.</ref>
It does not mean the students are endowed with expertise in the real world. Heathcote was clear about this.<ref>O'Neill, C. (2015) Dorothy Heathcote on Education and Drama: Essential Writing. Routledge, p.119.</ref> They are only experts inside the fiction, in the sense that they are taking on the powers and responsibilities of the team; they are not experts outside the fiction. Both the teacher and the students work collaboratively inside the fiction as people working for the same team. This means the teacher deliberately changes her power relationship with the students to one of equal power and authority. In this way decisions are made through discussion and distributed leadership. Outside the fiction, the teacher's authority remains unaffected.<ref>Taylor, T. (2016) p.166.</ref>
The creation of a fictional context where the students experiment with making decisions, taking on responsibilities, and meeting challenging situations, is a kind of 'safe zone' within the classroom. Unlike the real world where children would rarely, if ever, have these experiences, in an imaginary world they can explore, discuss, and evaluate them.<ref>Taylor, T. (2016) p.39.</ref> For Heathcote this is what she meant when she described her ideal classroom as a laboratory - "when you enter such a lab you bring in your knowledge and training with you and take on the mantle of responsibility that goes with the character of the setting. Above all, you know that the result of what you do there matter to someone other than yourself. Such settings are cells effecting change in society."<ref>Bolton (2003) p.126.</ref>
== Elements ==
Tim Taylor in his book, "A Beginner's Guide to Mantle of the Expert"<ref>Taylor, T. (2016).</ref> identifies nine elements to the Mantle of the Expert approach. These are:
# The creation of a fictional context – planned by the teacher and developed in collaboration with the students. The main functions of the fictional context are to create wider opportunities for curriculum learning; to make curriculum learning meaningful and purposeful; and to engage the students in curriculum study. # The use of a narrative – planned by the teacher and developed in collaboration with the students. The main functions of the narrative are to set up the context for the students; to offer the students a way into the fiction; and to make curriculum activities memorable, understandable, and coherent. # The use of inquiry questions. The main functions of inquiry questions are for students to explore, study, and analyse the curriculum; for students and teachers to work together in a community of learning; and for the teacher to create opportunities for students to assess, rethink, and shape the direction of the work as it develops. # The Expert Team. Planned by the teacher and developed in collaboration with the students. Expert teams are people with authority, power, and status; people with responsibilities and duties to others; a community with agreed values and a defined purpose; colleagues with a shared history of challenges, mistakes, and success; experts with training and experience # The client. Planned by the teacher. The purpose of the client is to generate purposeful activities for the team; create a focus for the team; reflect back to the team how they are performing and what they need to do to improve and develop; assess and evaluate the work of the team, requiring high standards and a focus on the commission; provide information, specialist knowledge, and experiences; make demands of the team. # The commission. Planned by the teacher and developed with the students. The function of the commission is to give purpose to the work of the team and, by extension, to the students' curriculum studies; focus the work and keep it on course; provide a goal for the work, something to strive for; create a sense of responsibility; generate self-worth and a sense of achievement. # Different points view. The purpose of providing the students with different points of view is to look at events from multiple perspectives; provide alternative attitudes, values, and beliefs; generate opportunities for exploring people's motivations; challenge the student's views and orthodox thinking; create opportunities to explore people and events in depth and complexity; experiment with different ways of dealing with challenges and problems. # Tension. Planned by the teacher and developed in collaboration with the students. The purpose of tension is to create excitement and interest; create productive energy, drawing on the students' excitement and commitment to events; generate opportunities to examine people's actions, motivations, and values; build resilience. # Drama conventions. Planned by the teacher and used in collaboration with the students. The purpose of drama conventions is to play with time – hold it, rewind it, jump forward; create opportunities for exploration, examination, discussion, and reflection; investigate people's actions, motivations, and values; give students the power to influence events; create a 'safe zone' that gives students the opportunity to experiment and explore different possibilities and choices.

The series premiered on the American [[cable television]] network [[IFC (U.S. TV channel)|IFC]] on May 3, 2013.{{cite web|title=Coming Soon: "Maron" with guest stars Judd Hirsch, Dave Foley, Adam Scott, Bobcat Goldthwait, Ileana Douglas |url=http://www.ifc.com/shows/maron/blog/2013/03/marc-maron-guest-stars-including-bobcat-goldthwait-ileana-douglas |publisher=[[IFC (U.S. TV channel)|IFC]] |accessdate=March 11, 2013 |date=March 11, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130312213843/http://www.ifc.com/shows/maron/blog/2013/03/marc-maron-guest-stars-including-bobcat-goldthwait-ileana-douglas |archivedate=March 12, 2013 |df= }} Maron, [[Denis Leary]], [[Jim Serpico]], Olivia Wingate, Sivert Glarum, Michael Jamin and [[Duncan Birmingham]] serve as the show's executive producers. In November 2015, the series was renewed for a thirteen-episode fourth season. On July 11, 2016, Maron announced on his ''WTF'' podcast that the series will not have a fifth season, with the season four finale serving as the series finale.{{cite web|last=Nededog |first=Jethro |url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/marc-maron-says-hes-ending-133025218.html |title=Marc Maron says that he's ending his IFC TV show: 'It's done' |publisher=Finance.yahoo.com |date=2016-07-11 |accessdate=2016-07-12}} The series finale aired on July 13, 2016. ==Cast and characters== * [[Marc Maron]] as a fictionalized version of himself ===Supporting=== * [[Josh Brener]] as Kyle, Marc's assistant * [[Dave Anthony]] as himself, Marc's pathetic friend * [[Andy Kindler]] as himself, Marc's other pathetic friend * [[Lucy Davis]] as Emily, Marc's manager * [[Nora Zehetner]] as Jen, Marc's girlfriend * [[Sally Kellerman]] as Toni Maron, Marc's mother * [[Judd Hirsch]] as Larry Maron, Marc's father * Troy Ruptash as Josh Maron, Marc's brother * [[Rick Shapiro]] as Bernie, Marc's eccentric neighbor ===Guest=== {{col-begin|width="50%"}} {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Steve Agee]] * [[Maria Bamford]] * [[Nate Bargatze]] * [[Peter Berman]] * [[CM Punk|Phil "CM Punk" Brooks]] * [[Bruce Bruce]] * [[Bill Burr]] * [[Louis C.K.]] * [[Colt Cabana]] * [[Wyatt Cenac]] * [[Carly Chaikin]] * [[David Cross]] * [[Whitney Cummings]] * [[Erin Daniels]] * [[Dov Davidoff]] * [[Lucy Davis]] * [[Joey Diaz]] * [[Illeana Douglas]] * [[Mark Duplass]] * [[Dave Foley]] * [[M.C. [[File:Tokyo 2020 mascots.png|thumb|Miraitowa (left), the official mascot of the [[2020 Summer Olympics]], and Someity (right), the official mascot of the [[2020 Summer Paralympics]]|300px|alt=On the left, a humanoid cartoon character with large ears whose body has blue-checkered patterns is pumping its fist. On the right, another humanoid cartoon character with pointy ears whose body has pink checkers is wearing a pink-checkered cape and also pumping its fist.]] {{2020 Summer Olympics}} {{2020 Summer Paralympics}} '''Miraitowa''' ({{Lang-ja|ミライトワ}}; pronounced "mee-rah-e-toh-wa"<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://tokyo2020.org/en/news/notice/20180722-01.html|title=Tokyo 2020 Mascots, Miraitowa and Someity have finally Debut!|last=|first=|date=22 July 2018|website=Tokyo 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180722120751/https://tokyo2020.org/en/news/notice/20180722-01.html|archive-date=22 July 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=22 July 2018}}</ref>{{Needs IPA|ja}}) is the [[List of Olympic mascots|official mascot]] of the [[2020 Summer Olympics]], and '''Someity''' ({{Lang-ja|ソメイティ}}; pronounced "soh-may-tee"<ref name=":2" />) is the [[List of Paralympic mascots|official mascot]] of the [[2020 Summer Paralympics]]. Both events are scheduled to be held in [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]]. The checkered design on both mascots was inspired by [[2020 Summer Olympics#Emblem|the Tokyo 2020 official logo]], while Someity's pink design was inspired by [[Cherry blossom|cherry blossom flowers]]. Both fictional characters have various superpowers, such as [[teleportation]].
Created by Japanese artist Ryo Taniguchi, the mascots were selected from a competition process which took place in late 2017 and early 2018. A total of 2,042 candidate designs were submitted to the [[Tokyo Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games|Tokyo 2020 Organising Committee]], which selected three pairs of unnamed mascot designs to present to Japanese elementary school students for the final decision. The results of the selection were announced on 28 February 2018, and the mascots were named on 22 July 2018. Miraitowa is named after the Japanese words for "future" and "eternity", and Someity is named after ''[[someiyoshino]]'', a type of cherry blossom. Someity's name also references the English phrase "so mighty". The mascots are expected to help finance the Tokyo Games through merchandising and licensing deals.
== History ==
=== Selection and naming process === In late 2017 and early 2018, the [[Tokyo Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games|Tokyo 2020 Organising Committee]] held a competition to determine the design of the 2020 mascots. A total of 2,042 design submissions were accepted between 1 August and 14 August 2017. The entries were then subjected to a series of format and design examinations led by media specialists and the Organising Committee's Mascot Selection Panel to determine whether they "would appeal to elementary school-aged children" and whether they "amply reflected the spirit of the Tokyo 2020 Games Vision".<ref name="tokyo2020_mascots">{{cite web|url=https://tokyo2020.jp/en/games/mascot/|title=Tokyo 2020 Games Mascots|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180301164629/https://tokyo2020.org/en/games/mascot/|archive-date=1 March 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=7 September 2017}}</ref>
{{multiple image|align=right|direction=vertical|header=Rejected mascot designs|image1=Tokyo 2020 mascot candidate pair B.jpg|caption1=Pair B, created by Kana Yano|image2=Tokyo 2020 mascot candidate pair C.jpg|caption2=Pair C, created by Sanae Akimoto}} By mid-October 2017, this process reduced the pool to a shortlist of three sets of mascot candidates, which were unveiled on 7 December 2017. Each set included two mascots: one for the Olympic Games and the other for the Paralympic Games.<ref name="tokyo2020_mascots" /> Between 11 December 2017 and 22 February 2018, an election was conducted across 16,769 [[Elementary schools in Japan|Japanese elementary schools]] to choose the winning entry, with each participating elementary school class allocated one vote.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2017/08/01/national/2020-tokyo-olympic-organizers-begin-soliciting-mascot-ideas/ |title=2020 Tokyo Olympic organizers begin soliciting mascot ideas |publisher=''[[The Japan Times]]'' |date=1 August 2017 |accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://olympics.nbcsports.com/2017/12/07/tokyo-olympic-mascot-photos-2020/ |title=Tokyo 2020 lets children choose mascots from 3 finalists |publisher=''[[NBC Sports]]'' |date=7 December 2017 |accessdate= 17 February 2018}}</ref><ref name=":1" /> In total, 205,755 elementary school classes participated in the election.<ref name=":1" />
{| class="wikitable" |+Results of the mascot selection !Pair !Designer !Votes received<ref name=":1" /> !Profile |- |'''A (winner)''' |'''Ryo Taniguchi''' ({{Lang-ja|text=谷口亮}}) |'''109,041''' |<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tokyo2020.org/en/special/mascot/candidate_1.html|title=Mascot Candidates A|website=Tokyo 2020|publisher=Tokyo Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180225144030/https://tokyo2020.org/en/special/mascot/candidate_1.html|archivedate=25 February 2018|dead-url=no|accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref> |- |B |Kana Yano ({{Lang-ja|矢野花奈}}) |61,423 |<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tokyo2020.org/en/special/mascot/candidate_2.html|title=Mascot Candidates B|website=Tokyo 2020|publisher=Tokyo Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180225144030/https://tokyo2020.org/en/special/mascot/candidate_1.html|archivedate=25 February 2018|dead-url=no|accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref> |- |C |Sanae Akimoto ({{Lang-ja|秋本早苗}}) |35,291 |<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tokyo2020.org/en/special/mascot/candidate_3.html|title=Mascot Candidates C|website=Tokyo 2020|publisher=Tokyo Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180225144157/https://tokyo2020.org/en/special/mascot/candidate_3.html|archivedate=25 February 2018|dead-url=no|accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref> |}
The results were announced without names on 28 February 2018. The winning entry was candidate pair A, created by Ryo Taniguchi.<ref name=":1">{{cite press release|title=Tokyo 2020 Unveils Olympic & Paralympic Mascots|url=https://tokyo2020.org/en/news/notice/20180228-01.html|accessdate=30 June 2018|publisher=[[Tokyo Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games]]|date=30 May 2018}}</ref> The Mascot Selection Panel held a vote on a shortlist of proposed names on 28 May 2018, and names with the most votes were subjected to a trademark verification process before they became official.<ref name="tenth">{{cite press release|title=10th Meeting of the Mascot Selection Panel|url=https://tokyo2020.org/en/news/notice/20180528-01.html|accessdate=30 May 2018|publisher=Tokyo Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games|date=28 February 2018}}</ref> The names of the mascots, Miraitowa and Someity, were announced when the mascots made their formal debut at a press event on 22 July 2018.<ref name=":3">{{cite news |title=Olympic mascots Miraitowa and Someity invoke the future and cherry trees for 2020 Games |url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2018/07/22/national/tokyo-games-organizers-introduce-mascots-miraitowa-someity-world/ |accessdate=22 July 2018 |work=The Japan Times |agency=AFP-JIJI |date=22 July 2018}}</ref>
== Characteristics == Miraitowa, the Olympic mascot, is a figure with blue-checkered patterns inspired by [[2020 Summer Olympics#Emblem|the Games' official logo]]. It is intended to embody "both old tradition and new innovation". The character has a "strong sense of justice" and is described as "very athletic". It has the ability to [[Teleportation|teleport]] anywhere instantly.<ref name="profile">{{cite web |title=Tokyo 2020 Games Mascots |url=https://tokyo2020.org/en/special/mascot/ |website=Tokyo 2020 |publisher=The Tokyo Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games |accessdate=30 June 2018 |language=en}}</ref> Miraitowa is named after the Japanese words ''mirai'' (future) and ''towa'' (eternity) combined.<ref name=":3" /> According to the Tokyo 2020 organizers, the name "was chosen to promote a future full of eternal hope in the hearts of people all over the world".<ref name=":2" />
[[File:Cerasus × yedoensis Akebono 01.jpg|thumb|Flowers of the [[cherry blossom]] ''[[Prunus × yedoensis]]'' ({{lang-ja|染井吉野|someiyoshino}}), the namesake of the Paralympic mascot]] Someity, the Paralympic mascot, is a figure with pink-checkered patterns inspired by [[Cherry blossom|cherry blossom flowers]] and also the Games' official logo. The character is described as "usually calm" but can become "very powerful when needed". The character has the special ability to flight using a pink-checkered cape and cherry blossom-shaped antenna to "talk to stones and the wind" and can also [[Telekenesis|move objects by looking at them]].<ref name="profile" /> Someity is named after ''[[someiyoshino]]'', a type of cherry blossom, and it is also intended to refer to the English phrase "so mighty".<ref name=":3" />
Although the two mascots have conflicting personalities, they nonetheless have a strong friendship and respect for each other.<ref name="profile" /> According to their fictional backgrounds, Miraitowa and Someity "live in the digital world", and through the Internet, they can transport themselves between the digital world and the [[real life|real world]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Tokyo 2020 Paralympic mascot named Someity |url=https://www.paralympic.org/news/tokyo-2020-paralympic-mascot-named-someity |website=Official website of the Paralympic Movement |publisher=International Paralympic Committee |accessdate=22 July 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.paralympic.org/news/tokyo-2020-paralympic-mascot-named-someity |archivedate=22 July 2018 |dead-url=no |date=22 July 2018}}</ref> According to Sadashige Aoki, an [[Advertising|advertising theory]] professor at [[Hosei University]], the mascots follow a Japanese tradition of "creating personalized characters out of nature — mountains, rivers, animals and plants", as well as a "tradition of animism, a belief that every natural thing has a soul".<ref name=":4" />
The mascots were designed by Japanese artist Ryo Taniguchi, who lives in the [[Fukuoka Prefecture]] in southern Japan. Taniguchi was persuaded by his father, who is also an illustrator, to study art at [[Cabrillo College]] in California.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2018/05/ad717c3d31b2-feature-tokyo-2020-mascot-designer-draws-inspiration-from-the-scenic-route.html|title=Tokyo 2020 mascot designer draws inspiration from the scenic route|last=Hueston|first=Dave|date=3 May 2018|website=Kyodo News|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180708083708oe_/https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2018/05/ad717c3d31b2-feature-tokyo-2020-mascot-designer-draws-inspiration-from-the-scenic-route.html|archive-date=8 July 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=8 July 2018}}</ref> He has illustrated English-language textbooks for Japanese children.<ref name=":0" /><ref name="forbes">{{cite web |last1=Adelstein |first1=Jake |title=Japan's Cute Blue And Pink Mascots Are Here To Boost The Tokyo 2020 Olympics |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/adelsteinjake/2018/03/01/japans-cute-blue-and-pink-mascots-are-here-to-boost-the-tokyo-2020-olympics/#1d87970776e9 |website=Forbes |accessdate=8 July 2018|archive-url=http://archive.today/2018.07.08-082056/https://www.forbes.com/sites/adelsteinjake/2018/03/01/japans-cute-blue-and-pink-mascots-are-here-to-boost-the-tokyo-2020-olympics/%231d87970776e9|archive-date=8 July 2018|dead-url=no}}</ref> Taniguchi was uninvolved in the naming of the mascots, though he did attend a screening at which various naming proposals were introduced.<ref name=":0" /> As part of the agreement to use the mascots, Taniguchi transferred [[intellectual property]] rights to the mascots to the Olympic and Paralympic committees, and as a result, he will not receive any [[royalty payment]]s from mascot-related licensing.<ref name="reuters">{{cite web |last1=Gallagher |first1=Chris |title=Olympics: Futuristic pointy-eared mascots chosen for Tokyo 2020 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-olympics-2020-mascots/olympics-futuristic-pointy-eared-mascots-chosen-for-tokyo-2020-idUSKCN1GC0Q5 |website=Reuters |accessdate=9 July 2018 |date=27 February 2018}}</ref>
== Media ==
=== Merchandising === The mascots are expected to generate revenue to help finance the Tokyo Games.<ref name=":4" /> An Olympic official expected the mascots to generate $130 million ({{JPY|14.4 billion}}) in revenue from licensing and merchandising.<ref name=":0" /> The organizers of Tokyo 2020 had been criticized for its budget management.<ref name="forbes" /><ref name="reutersbudget" /> According to ''[[Reuters]]'', a 2016 study found that overall expenses for the Olympics could be "four times the initial estimate made in the bid process".<ref name="reutersbudget">{{Cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-olympics-2020-briefing/tokyo-2020-must-address-questions-says-iocs-coates-idUSKBN1HU0B9|title=Tokyo 2020 must address questions, says IOC's Coates|last=Tarrant|first=Jack|date=22 April 2018|website=Reuters|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180424135407/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-olympics-2020-briefing/tokyo-2020-must-address-questions-says-iocs-coates-idUSKBN1HU0B9|archive-date=24 April 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=22 July 2018}}</ref> Tokyo 2020 must transfer [[Intellectual property|intellectual property rights]] to the mascots to the [[International Olympic Committee]] and the [[International Paralympic Committee]] after the Games are concluded, which would prevent Tokyo from licensing and developing the mascots after the Games are over.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2018/01/23/business/cuddly-cute-will-japans-olympic-mascots-cash-cows/|title=Cuddly and cute, but will Japan’s Olympic mascots be cash cows?|last=|first=|date=23 January 2018|website=The Japan Times|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180123123831/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2018/01/23/business/cuddly-cute-will-japans-olympic-mascots-cash-cows/|archive-date=23 January 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=8 July 2018}}</ref>
From late July to early September 2018, a "Mascot House" was located on the first floor of the [[Tokyo Midtown Hibiya]] building, where visitors could take photos with the mascots and purchase licensed merchandise featuring the mascots.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tokyo2020.org/en/special/mascot/|title=Tokyo 2020 Mascots|website=Tokyo 2020|publisher=Tokyo Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180816205001/https://tokyo2020.org/en/special/mascot/|archivedate=16 August 2018|accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref>
== Reception ==
The public reaction to the mascot selection was "generally positive", according to an article published on ''[[Forbes]]''' website in March 2018 by contributor Jake Adelstein. Adelstein described the mascots as "cute", though he commented that "there was some criticism of the futuristic blue and pink characters falling clearly into traditional gender roles". Adelstein speculated that the mascots would support the Olympics in Tokyo financially.<ref name="forbes" /> Multiple observers compared the design of the mascots to that of the ''[[Pokémon]]'' franchise.<ref name="forbes" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://kotaku.com/the-tokyo-olympic-mascots-look-like-pokemon-1823383301|title=The Tokyo Olympic Mascots Look Like Pokémon|last=Ashcraft|first=Brian|date=28 February 2018|website=Kotaku|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180307160208/https://kotaku.com/the-tokyo-olympic-mascots-look-like-pokemon-1823383301|archive-date=7 March 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=8 July 2018}}</ref><ref name="deadspin">{{cite web |last1=McQuade |first1=Dan |title=Will Japan’s Olympic Mascot Be A Soohorang Or An Izzy? |url=https://deadspin.com/will-japan-s-olympic-mascot-be-a-soohorang-or-an-izzy-1823406254 |website=Deadspin |publisher=Gizmodo Media Group |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180301004148/https://deadspin.com/will-japan-s-olympic-mascot-be-a-soohorang-or-an-izzy-1823406254 |archive-date=1 March 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=12 July 2018 |date=28 February 2018}}</ref> An article by [[Agence France-Presse]] described the [[social media]] reaction to the mascot selection on as "mixed". Some users commented that the mascots were "very Japanese and very cute", while others commented that the mascots should have been "more round" or "more huggable". Other commentators said that the selected design "appealed more to children whereas adults preferred the softer and more traditional options".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/doe-eyed-superhero-picked-for-tokyo-2020-mascot|title=Doe-eyed superhero picked for Tokyo 2020 mascot|date=28 February 2018|work=The Straits Times|accessdate=11 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180228092454/https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/doe-eyed-superhero-picked-for-tokyo-2020-mascot|archive-date=28 February 2018|dead-url=no|publisher=Singapore Press Holdings|agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] (AFP)}}</ref>
Dan McQuade wrote in an article in sports news website ''[[Deadspin]]'' that it will be difficult for Miraitowa and Someity to match the popularity of [[Soohorang and Bandabi]], the mascots of the [[2018 Winter Olympics]], citing statements from the [[BBC]], which wrote that the 2020 mascots "have a tough act to follow", and ''[[The Japan Times]]'', which wrote in a headline that the success of Soohorang and Bandabi "leaves Japan in a bind".<ref name="deadspin" /><ref>{{cite web |title=Tokyo 2020 Olympic mascots unveiled after children's vote |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-43221985 |website=BBC |accessdate=12 July 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180228163418/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-43221985 |archivedate=28 February 2018 |dead-url=no |date=28 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Tanaka |first1=Yukari |title=Success of Pyeongchang Olympic mascots leaves Japan in a bind |url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2018/02/24/national/media-national/success-pyeongchang-olympic-mascots-leaves-japan-bind/ |website=The Japan Times |accessdate=12 July 2018 |archiveurl=http://archive.today/2018.07.12-084402/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2018/02/24/national/media-national/success-pyeongchang-olympic-mascots-leaves-japan-bind/%23.W0cUudLLfK4 |archivedate=12 July 2018 |dead-url=no |date=24 February 2018}}</ref> James Dator, in a blog entry published on the sports news website ''[[SB Nation]]'', wrote that there is "nothing functionally wrong" with the mascot design, but felt that Sanae Akimoto's pair C was a superior candidate and should have been chosen instead. Dator also argued that children should not have been the ones to make the final decision.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sbnation.com/lookit/2018/2/28/17061668/tokyo-2020-mascots-the-kids-are-wrong|title=Tokyo 2020 mascots aren’t Stoned Cat and Leaf Bear because kids have no taste|last=Dator|first=James|date=28 February 2018|website=SB Nation|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180228202528/https://www.sbnation.com/lookit/2018/2/28/17061668/tokyo-2020-mascots-the-kids-are-wrong|archive-date=28 February 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=8 July 2018}}</ref> On the other hand, Naoki Ogi, a Japanese [[pedagogy]] expert, emphasized the importance of the role of children in selecting the mascots, as opposed to adults.<ref name="forbes" /> Japanese author Rurika Suzuki said that the mascots have a "a very Japanese [[anime]] like quality", describing them as "brilliant and sporty and perfect for the Olympics".<ref name="forbes" />

'''Modesty in medical settings''' refers to the practices and equipment used to preserve patient [[modesty]] in medical examination and clinics.
==Tools for modesty==
Prior to the invention of the [[stethoscope]], a physician who wanted to perform [[auscultation]] to listen to [[heart sounds]] or noise inside a body would have to physically place their ear against the body of the person being examined.<ref name="Roguin">{{Cite journal | author = Ariel Roguin | title = Rene Theophile Hyacinthe Laennec (1781-1826): the man behind the stethoscope | journal = Clinical Medicine & Research | volume = 4 | issue = 3 | pages = 230–235 | date=September 2006 | pmid = 17048358 | doi=10.3121/cmr.4.3.230 | pmc=1570491}}</ref> In 1816, male physician [[René Laennec]] invented the stethoscope as a way to respect the modesty of a female patient, as it would have been awkward for him to put his ear on her chest.<ref name="Roguin"/>
[[Hospital gowns]] increase modesty as compared to the patient presenting nude, but in the past have been odd clothing which exposes the body.<ref name="Shefali">{{cite web |url= https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2015/04/hospital-gowns-get-a-makeover/389258/ |title=Hospital Gowns Get a Makeover — The Atlantic |first=Shefali |last=Luthra |work=theatlantic.com |date=4 April 2015 |accessdate=13 April 2015}}</ref> Some contemporary changes to the design of hospital gowns are proposed.<ref name="Shefali"/>
==Society and culture== In places with more [[cultural diversity]] it becomes more likely that people will make new and different requests for modesty in health care.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Seibert|first1=PS|last2=Stridh-Igo|first2=P|last3=Zimmerman|first3=CG|title=A checklist to facilitate cultural awareness and sensitivity.|journal=Journal of Medical Ethics|date=June 2002|volume=28|issue=3|pages=143–6|pmid=12042396|doi=10.1136/jme.28.3.143|pmc=1733575}}</ref>
==Special populations== Sometimes women do not access healthcare because of modesty concerns.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Schoueri-Mychasiw|first1=N|last2=Campbell|first2=S|last3=Mai|first3=V|title=Increasing screening mammography among immigrant and minority women in Canada: a review of past interventions.|journal=[[Journal of Immigrant and Minority Health]]|date=February 2013|volume=15|issue=1|pages=149–58|doi=10.1007/s10903-012-9612-8|pmid=22466249}}</ref>
Muslims in non-Muslim societies sometimes make requests for modesty.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rassool|first1=GH|title=Cultural competence in nursing Muslim patients.|journal=Nursing times|date=April 2015|volume=111|issue=14|pages=12–5|pmid=26182584}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Boucher|first1=NA|last2=Siddiqui|first2=EA|last3=Koenig|first3=HG|title=Supporting Muslim Patients During Advanced Illness.|journal=The Permanente journal|date=2017|volume=21|doi=10.7812/TPP/16-190|pmid=28609264|pmc=5469433}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.patientmodesty.org/ patientmodesty.org/], a United States-based nonprofit organization advocating for modesty

[[File:Dorothy Gish 6 cropped.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Dorothy Gish]] sporting a mushroom-brimmed hat in 1918]]
A '''mushroom hat''' (also sometimes referred to as a '''mushroom brim hat''' or '''dish hat''') is a millinery style in which the brim of the hat tilts downwards, resembling the shape of a mushroom (or dish). It is a style that first emerged in the 1870s and 1880s, when it was usually made of straw. It became fashionable again from around 1907 to the late 1920s; these versions featured a distinctly downturned brim although the size and shape of the crown varied according to prevailing fashions.
A new and exaggerated version of the mushroom hat was popularised by [[Christian Dior]] in 1947 as part of his [[Christian Dior S.A.#The .22New Look.22|"New Look"]] collection. This style generally had a minimal crown and a very wide brim, with some models resembling a [[flying saucer]].
==History of the design== [[File:Pierre-Auguste Renoir 093.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Early mushroom hats were of straw. Portrait by [[Pierre-Auguste Renoir]], 1879]]
The defining characteristic of mushroom hats is their downturned brim, resembling a mushroom or toadstool.<ref name="Dictionary Brooks Picken">{{cite book|last1=Brooks Picken |first1=Mary |title=A Dictionary of Costume and Fashion: Historic and Modern|date=2010|publisher=Dover Publications|location=United States |isbn=0486402940 |pages=138 |edition=1999 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=CbOI4TCcnbQC&pg=PA165&lpg=PA165&dq=mary+brooks+picken+%2B+mushroom+hat#v=onepage&q=mary%20brooks%20picken%20%2B%20mushroom%20hat&f=false |accessdate=6 January 2015}}</ref> In the 1870s, designs in straw shaped like a mushroom became popular. These had a small crown trimmed with ribbons, flowers and – in the 1880s – bird decorations.<ref name="The Dictionary of Fashion History">{{cite book |last1=Cumming |first1=Valerie |last2=Cunnington|first2=C.W. |last3=Cunnington |first3=P. |title=The Dictionary of Fashion History |date=2010 |publisher=Berg |location=Oxford |isbn=9781847887382|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=e3evAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA138&lpg=PA138&dq=valerie+cumming+%2B+mushroom+hat#v=onepage&q=valerie%20cumming%20%2B%20mushroom%20hat&f=false|accessdate=27 October 2014}}</ref>
[[File:Ion Theodorescu-Sion - Iluzie optică, Furnica, 30 oct 1908.JPG|thumb|150px|A 1908 cartoon by [[Ion Theodorescu-Sion]] satirising the popularity of mushroom hats]]
In 1907, mushroom hats in both straw and felt became popular. Such was their ubiquity that [[Evelyn Sharp (suffragist)|Evelyn Sharp]] lambasted them in an editorial in ''[[The Guardian]]'', writing: "For about six months have we endured the sight of mushroom shapes in every kind of straw trimmed with a fringed silk scarf. I suppose there was some attraction in the mushroom hat when it was first designed, and I can still see its charms when it is very small and very flexible....worn by somebody in a motor car. But this autumnal growth of felt fungi deserves nothing but condemnation".<ref name="The Guardian Sharp">{{cite news|last1=Sharp|first1=Evelyn|title=The Felt Hat: contrasts in the field of choice|publisher=The Guardian|date=10 October 1907}}</ref> Her words fell on deaf ears as the popularity of mushroom shapes persisted. In 1909, a full-page advertisement in ''[[The Times]]'' describing [[Selfridges|Selfridge & Co]]'s millinery choices detailed a mushroom brim hat decorated with [[Ostrich#Hunting and farming|ostrich feathers]].<ref name="The Times 38936">{{cite news|title=The Millinery Department at Selfridge's|issue=38936|publisher=The Times|date=17 April 1909}}</ref> In the same year, [[Dickins & Jones]] offered a: "becoming mushroom hat...trimmed with wide Velvet Ribbon and a Large Posy of Flowers at side".<ref name="The Times 38950">{{cite news|title=Millinery|issue=38950|publisher=The Times|date=4 May 1909}}</ref> By 1915, variations on the design for younger girls included almost brimless mushroom models – similar to a [[Cloche hat|cloche]] or [[Bucket hat|bucket]] hat.<ref name="The Times 40798">{{cite news|title=Children's hats|issue=40798|publisher=The Times|date=10 March 1915}}</ref>
===1920s variations=== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 102-10749, Isabelle Rockefeller.jpg|thumb|150px|1920s mushroom hats often resembled the [[cloche hat]], but with the addition of a neat brim, such as this model worn by [[Isabel Rockefeller]]]] The mushroom hat was fashionable throughout the 1920s, with [[Mary, Princess Royal and Countess of Harewood|Princess Mary]] choosing a mushroom shape with a blue lace-covered brim for the opening day of [[Ascot Racecourse|Ascot]] in 1920.<ref name="The Times 42438">{{cite news|title=Ascot: Brilliant First Day|issue=42438|publisher=The Times|date=16 June 1920|ref=p. 17}}</ref> Five years later, the [[Queen Mother|Duchess of York]] chose a mushroom design trimmed with vivid orange [[osprey]] feathers tucked at either side of the brim for Ascot's Ladies' Day race meeting.<ref name="The Times">{{cite news|title=Ladies' Day at Ascot|issue=43992|publisher=The Times|date=19 June 1925}}</ref>
It was a style that could incorporate the fashions for snug-fitting cloche-like designs or taller crowned hats. A fashion editorial of 1921 noted the value of wider-brimmed models: "Plentiful sunshine has served to emphasize the advantages of a mushroom hat, which with its adequate protection often makes a sunshade unnecessary".<ref name="The Times 42777">{{cite news|title=London fashions: some holiday dresses|issue=42777|publisher=The Times|date=20 July 1921}}</ref> In the same year, velvet for babies were described as among the newest children's millinery.<ref name="The Times 42816">{{cite news|title=Autumn campaign of the shops: Fashions for nursery and ballroom|issue=42816|publisher=The Times|date=3 September 1921|ref=pg.10}}</ref> The hat design lent itself to ornate decorations with ribbon and feather trims and veils. It could also be made in a variety of materials, from straw for summer to felt or stiffened silk for winter; in 1925, [[Harvey Nichols]] offered a selection of mushroom hats for the autumn season in the latest [[velour]] fabric.<ref name="The Times 44024">{{cite news|title=New Velour Hats|issue=44024|publisher=The Times|date=27 July 1925}}</ref>
==1940s "New Look" adaptation== A new variety of mushroom hat (also known as the dish hat) appeared at Dior's first fashion show on 12 February 1947.<ref name="Hatatorium Grantland">{{cite book|last1=Grantland|first1=Brenda|last2=Robak|first2=Mary|title=Hatatorium: An essential guide for hat collectors|date=2011|publisher=Brenda Grantland|location=Mill Valley, CA|isbn=9780984785902|pages=72–3|edition=1st|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=HLEK49A-LUAC&pg=PA152&lpg=PA152&dq=hatatorium+%2B+cossack&source=bl&ots=cN_dDYIZ6O&sig=wqKfSvKReaPp2IOyTYfS6S_VcLw&hl=en&sa=X&ei=BseyVJbkFOeP7AaS6IGoDg&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=hatatorium%20%2B%20cossack&f=false|accessdate=14 November 2014}}</ref> The hat balanced the neat jacket with nipped-in waist and full [[Tulle|tulle-lined]] skirt, heralding a new lavishness in fabric and silhouette – what editor of American ''[[Harper's Bazaar]]'' [[Carmel Snow]] described at first viewing as a "new look".<ref name="Vogue Italy Pizzi">{{cite news|last1=Pizzi|first1=Sarah|title=Italian Vogue Encyclo: Christian Dior|url=http://www.vogue.it/en/encyclo/designers/d/christian-dior|accessdate=9 January 2015|publisher=Vogue Italy}}</ref>
By 1956, the fashion for new shapes meant a huge variety of options, as noted by ''The Guardian'''s fashion correspondent Phyllis Heathcote: "Flower-pots, sugar-loaves, mushrooms, melons, muffins – all these have inspired Paris milliners this season". Of the mushroom look, she added: "This may be small and snugly rounded, like the little pink 'Champignon de Paris' (Chabeau makes one of these in fine straw with a goffered frill of organdy under the brim that somehow carries the model away back to the source of its inspiration)...or it is wide and gently curving at the brim like the larger and flatter field variety. On these wider shapes go flat the airier techniques that the spring hat demands. Laizes of all kinds; fine picot straws, satin straws, gros-grain, short-pile summer velvet, raffia, coarse tulle, jersey, printed taffeta, crin, organdy, chiffon, and a great many flowers".<ref name="The Guardian Heathcote">{{cite news|last1=Heathcote|first1=Phyllis|title=Paris hats in variety: Flower-pot, sugar-loaf and mushroom inspiration|publisher=The Guardian|date=30 January 1956|ref=pg. 4}}</ref> Other names for the variations that emerged include the mushroom cloche, a diminutive version of Dior's oversized dish.<ref name="Hatatorium Grantland 1">{{cite book|last1=Grantland|first1=Brenda|last2=Robak|first2=Mary|title=Hatatorium: An essential guide for hat collectors|date=2011|publisher=Brenda Grantland|location=Mill Valley, CA|isbn=9780984785902|page=78|edition=1st|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=HLEK49A-LUAC&pg=PA48&lpg=PA48&dq=hatatorium+%2B+mushroom+cloche&source=bl&ots=cN_dDYI0aT&sig=K9vVcHdTZ0EITbCPRZR1igS2cbg&hl=en&sa=X&ei=X8iyVJLtHoPV7gaInYHIAg&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=hatatorium%20%2B%20mushroom%20cloche&f=false|accessdate=14 November 2014}}</ref>
Wide-brimmed mushroom hats continued to be popular throughout the 1950s and early '60s, with other designers incorporating the wide hat profile. Adaptations included [[Pierre Balmain|Balmain's]] spring 1955 side-swept mushroom hat – a design in which the downward-curved brim of the hat dipped low on one side of the face and was tilted upwards on the other, forming an almost triangular profile.<ref name="The Times 53159">{{cite news|title=Paris Hat Fashions|issue=53159|publisher=The Times|date=7 February 1955|ref=p.7}}</ref>
In 1959, ''[[The Observer]]'' reported that mushroom hats were big news at Ascot for milliners such as [[Rose Vernier]]: "The majority of her clients wanted big tulle mushrooms, but the younger girls asked for the youthful tailored shapes of medium size – when they were not demanding outsize Gigi bretons".<ref name="The Observer 140659">{{cite news|title=Mushroom look for hats at Ascot|publisher=The Observer|date=14 June 1959|ref=pg. 18}}</ref>
In 1963, [[Cristóbal Balenciaga|Balenciaga]] included extreme saucer-shaped versions of the design in velvet, worn with a tapered [[Raglan sleeve|raglan-sleeved]] black [[Crêpe (textile)|wool crepe]] dress and lime yellow [[Twill|twill coat]] with pleated shoulder.<ref name="The Times 55807.">{{cite news|title=Balenciaga and Givenchy designs for autumn|issue=55807|publisher=The Times|date=16 September 1963|ref=pg. 13}}</ref> By 1964, a more [[Bucket hat|bucket-shaped]] line had re-emerged. [[Nina Ricci (designer)|Ricci]] showed a high-crowned white mushroom hat worn with a double-breasted [[gaberdine]] suit in the spring shows.<ref name="The Times 55925">{{cite news|title=Fashion in Paris|issue=55925|publisher=The Times|date=3 February 1964|ref=pg. 13}}</ref>
<gallery widths="140px" heights="200px"> File:Christian Dior (Moscow exhibition, 2011) 26.jpg|[[Christian Dior SA|Dior]] mushroom hat, with [[Christian Dior S.A.#The .22New Look.22|"New Look"]] outfit from 1947 – displayed in Moscow at a 2011 exhibition File:Queen Elizabeth in Aden 1954.jpg|[[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth]] in an adapted mushroom design in [[Aden]], 1954 File:Flickr - Government Press Office (GPO) - Gottex Bathing Suits.jpg|Mushroom hat photographed in 1961 File:Amy Alkon in hat.jpg|[[Amy Alkon]] in oversized black mushroom-brim design by milliner Amy Downs, 2009 </gallery>
===Revivals=== The mushroom shape has had a number of revivals in high fashion. During the mid 1980s, [[Frederick Fox (milliner)|Frederick Fox]] created a much-photographed mushroom-style design for [[Diana, Princess of Wales]] – worn tilted and known as the 'flying saucer'.<ref name="DT 131213">{{cite news|title=Frederick Fox – milliner|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/culture-obituaries/10516984/Frederick-Fox-obituary.html|accessdate=12 January 2015|publisher=Daily Telegraph|date=13 December 2013}}</ref> More recently, [[Stephen Jones (milliner)|Stephen Jones]] designed oversized hats in fur – including mushroom-like designs – for the fall/winter 2012 [[Marc Jacobs]]' show at [[New York Fashion Week]].<ref name="Vogue April 2012">{{cite news|title=Easter Hats|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/favourites-of-vogue/2012/4/easter-hats/gallery/737186|accessdate=12 January 2015|work=Vogue|date=April 2012}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Cartwheel hat]] * [[Cloche hat]] * [[Lampshade hat]]

'''Seoul''' has been known in the past by the successive names '''[[Wiryeseong]]''' ({{Korean|hangul=위례성 |hanja={{lang|ko|慰禮城}}}}, [[Baekje]] era), '''Namgyeong''' ({{Korean|labels=no|hangul=남경 |hanja={{lang|ko|南京}}}}, [[Goryeo]] era), '''Hanseong''' ({{Korean|labels=no|hangul=한성 |hanja={{lang|ko|漢城}}}}, [[Joseon]] era) or '''Hanyang''' ({{Korean|labels=no|hangul=한양 |hanja={{lang|ko|漢陽}}}}). During the period of Japanese invasion and colonization (1910-1945), [[Seoul]] was named to the [[Japanese language|Japanese]] {{Nihongo|'''[[Keijō]]'''|けいじょう or 京城}} or '''Gyeongseong''' ({{Korean|labels=no|hangul=경성 |hanja={{lang|ko|京城}}}}) (in Korean). Its current name is ''Seoul'', and this name has been in use since at least 1882, at times concurrently with other names.<ref>{{cite web |author=the Seoul Searcher |url=http://theseoulsearcher.com/wordpress/index.php/2010/07/28/seoul-the-name-of-the-city/ |title=Was Seoul Always Called Seoul? |publisher=Wordpress |date=2010-07-28 |accessdate=2010-08-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20100807202603/http://theseoulsearcher.com/wordpress/index.php/2010/07/28/seoul-the-name-of-the-city/ |archivedate=2010-08-07 |df= }}</ref>
==Etymology of "Seoul"== Seoul originated from the [[Korean language|Korean]] word “seo'ul” meaning "[[capital city]]". An etymological hypothesis presumes that the origin of the native word “seo'ul” derives from the native name ''Seorabeol'' ({{Korean |hangul=서라벌 |hanja={{lang|ko|徐羅伐}}}}), which originally referred to [[Gyeongju]], the capital of [[Silla]], then called ''Geumseong'' ({{Korean|labels=no|hangul=금성 |hanja={{lang|ko|金城}}}}).
==Chinese name for Seoul== Unlike most place names in Korea, "Seoul" has no corresponding [[hanja]] ([[Chinese characters]] used in the [[Korean language]]), although its name is presumed to derive from {{lang|ko|徐羅伐}} (''Seorabeol''), so Chinese-speaking countries for decades have referred to the city by its former name: {{lang|zh-hant|漢城}} ("{{lang|zh-Latn|Hànchéng}}" in [[Standard Mandarin|Mandarin]], "Hon Sing" in [[Standard Cantonese|Cantonese]] and "Hoe Zen" in [[Shanghainese]]). On a 1751 map of China and Korea prepared in France, Seoul was marked as "King-Ki-Tao, Capitale de la Coree", using an approximation of the Chinese pronunciation of [[Gyeonggi Province]] ({{lang|zh-hant|京畿道}}). The use of "King-Ki-Tao" to refer to Seoul was repeated again on the 1851 Tallis/Rapkin map of both Japan and Korea.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.antiquemapsandprints.com/japan--corea-yedo-tokyo-king-ki-tao-seoul-koreatallisrapkin-1851-map-209620-p.asp |title=JAPAN & COREA': Yedo (Tokyo) King-ki-Tao (Seoul). Korea.TALLIS/RAPKIN 1851 map |website=Antiquemapsandprints.com}}</ref> For a time during the late 1940s and early 1950s, the transliterated name {{lang|zh-Latn|Sūwū}} ({{zh|labels=no |t=蘇烏}}), which closely resembles to the English pronunciation for Seoul, was used.
This often caused problems in translation, as in [[Korean Language|Korean]], the terms "Seoul" and "Hanseong" are considered different. There exist many institutions and entities, most of them having no connections whatsoever, which use the two names. When the names of these institutions and entities are translated into Chinese, both "Seoul" and "Hanseong" were automatically translated to {{lang|zh-hant|漢城}} ({{lang|zh-Latn|Hànchéng}}). Typical examples of such errors in translation included [[Seoul National University]] versus [[Hansung University]], which both would be translated to {{lang|zh-hant|漢城大學}}, as well as [[Seoul Science High School]] versus [[Hansung Science High School]].
The problem, along with the confusion it caused for years, was solved in January 2005, when the Seoul City Government under then mayor Lee Myung Bak publicly requested that the Chinese name of the city be changed to {{lang|zh-hant|首爾}} ({{zh|p=Shǒu'ěr}}), written as {{lang|zh-hans|首尔}} in [[Simplified Chinese character|simplified Chinese]] in mainland China. The name was chosen by a select committee out of two names, the other being {{lang|zh-hant|首午爾}} ({{zh|links=no |p=Shǒuwu'ěr}}).
The chosen name is a close [[transliteration]] of Seoul in [[Mandarin Chinese]]; {{lang|zh|{{linktext|首}}}} ({{lang|zh-Latn|shǒu}}) can also mean "first" or "capital". For a some time after the name change, Chinese-language news media have used both names interchangeably during their publications or broadcasts ({{lang|zh-hant|首爾 [漢城]}} in print,<ref>{{cite news |script-title=zh:壹蘋果旅遊網－南韓－首爾﹝漢城﹞ |trans-title=NextMedia Travel: Seoul, South Korea)|url=http://hk.travel.nextmedia.com/index.php?fuseaction=cityguide.CityFact&cityID=4307 |language=zh-hk |accessdate=30 July 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714202836/http://hk.travel.nextmedia.com/index.php?fuseaction=cityguide.CityFact&cityID=4307|archivedate=14 July 2011|df=}}</ref> {{lang|zh-hant|首爾, 以前的漢城}}<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8lrHBu4rfjU</ref> [literally: Shouer, formerly Hancheng] in television and radio). Despite the adoption of {{lang|zh-Latn|Shǒu'ěr}} ({{lang|zh-hant|首爾}}) in Chinese media, the name {{lang|zh-Latn|Hànchéng}} ({{lang|zh-hant|漢城}}) is still widely used by some Chinese people.
For some time,{{when|date=May 2018}} [[Mainland China|Mainland Chinese]] media refused to adopt the new name, claiming that Chinese people have the right to choose how they name other cities around the world (see [[Exonym and endonym]]). They relented by the end of the year.{{year needed|date=May 2018}}
This change was intended for Chinese speakers only, and has no effect on the Korean language name. The new name would be written and pronounced 수이 (Su-i) in Korean. Some linguists have criticized the selection of the new name, claiming that its pronunciation in Korean bears no resemblance to the native name at all, and that its intended representation of the Korean pronunciation, while effective in Mandarin, is lost in other regional dialects, such as in [[Cantonese]], where the name is pronounced "sau2 yi5", or in [[Shanghainese]], in which the new name ({{lang|zh-hant|首爾}}) is pronounced "sew2 el3". These critics have said that the names "{{lang|zh|西蔚}}" or "{{lang|zh|徐蔚}}" (the latter being the ancient name of Seoul) would have been much more effective in representing the city's Korean name.
==Gyeongseong== {{Infobox Korean name |title=Gyeongseong |hangul=경성 |hanja={{lang|ko|京城}} |rr=Gyeongseong |mr=Kyŏngsŏng |context=old }} "Gyeongseong" is a [[Sino-Korean vocabulary|Sino-Korean word]] for "capital city" (''Gyeong'' ({{lang|ko|경; {{linktext|京}}}}) means "capital" and ''seong'' ({{lang|ko|성; {{linktext|城}}}}) means "walled city"). It was in occasional use to refer to Seoul throughout the [[Joseon|Joseon dynasty]], having earlier referred to the capitals of [[Goryeo]] and [[Silla]]. The term came into much wider use during the [[Korea under Japanese rule|period of Japanese rule]], because it is also the [[Korean language|Korean]] form of {{Nihongo|Keijō|京城}}, the former [[Japanese language|Japanese]] name used for Seoul during [[Korea under Japanese rule|the colonial rule]].
Seoul was called Hanseong ({{lang|ko|漢城}}) or Hanyang ({{lang|ko|漢陽}}) during the [[Joseon|Joseon dynasty]], but the city's main railway station, [[Seoul Station]], opened with the name "Gyeongseong Station" ({{lang|ko|京城驛}}) in 1900, which it retained until 1905. It was called Gyeongseong Station again from 1915 to 1947, when it assumed its current name.
''Gyeong'' is still used to refer to Seoul in the names of various railway lines and freeways, including:
*[[Gyeongbu Line]] (''Gyeongbuseon'' ({{lang|ko|경부선; 京釜線}}) in Korean) and [[Gyeongbu Expressway]] (''Gyeongbu Gosok Doro''; {{lang|ko|경부 고속 도로}}) between [[Seoul]] and [[Busan]] ({{lang|ko|부산; 釜山}}); *[[Gyeongin Line]] (''Gyeonginseon''; {{lang|ko|경인선; 京仁線}}) and [[Gyeongin Expressway]] (''Gyeongin Gosok Doro''; {{lang|ko|경인 고속 도로}}) between [[Seoul]] and [[Incheon]] ({{lang|ko|인천; 仁川}}); *[[Gyeongui Line]] (''Gyeonguiseon''; {{lang|ko|경의선; 京義線}}) between [[Seoul]] and Dorasan (the ''ui'' comes from ''Sinuiju'' ({{lang|ko|新義州}}), the [[Revised Romanization of Korea|Revised Romanized]] spelling of [[Sinuiju|Sinŭiju]] ({{lang|ko|신의주}}) in [[North Korea]], the line's original terminus on the Chinese border—see the article on the [[Gyeongui Line]] for details); *[[Gyeongwon Line]] (''Gyeongwonseon''; {{lang|ko|경원선; 京元線}}) between [[Seoul]] and Shintanni (originally the line went to [[Wonsan]] ({{lang|ko|원산; 元山}}) in what is now [[North Korea]]); and *[[Gyeongchun Line]] (''Gyeongchunseon''; {{lang|ko|경춘선; 京春線}}) between [[Seoul]] and [[Chuncheon]] ({{lang|ko|춘천; 春川}}) in [[Gangwon-do (South Korea)|Gangwon]] Province.

'''National Philanthropy Day''' (November 15) is an observance designated by the [[Association of Fundraising Professionals]] (AFP). It is a day to celebrate [[Charity_(practice)|charitable activities]], in the form of donated financial, in-kind and [[volunteering]] support. It is celebrated with blog postings by AFP highlighting outstanding charitable activities, as well as luncheons and awards throughout the USA by different AFP chapters.
==Background== The association has been celebrating National Philanthropy Day since 1986, when then US President [[Ronald Reagan]] signed a proclamation recognizing November 15 as National Philanthropy Day in the US.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=36729|title=Ronald Reagan: Remarks on the Observance of National Philanthropy Day|publisher=}}</ref> In 2013, the [[Canadian government]] signed into law a proclamation celebrating November 15 as National Philanthropy Day annually. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://npdlove.com/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-06-19 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140517232753/http://npdlove.com/ |archivedate=May 17, 2014 |df= }}, National Philanthropy Day, nplove.com, retrieved 19 June 2017</ref>
National Philanthropy Day is registered with the [[United States Patent and Trademark Office|USPTO]] and the [[U.S. Department of Commerce]]. The official National Philanthropy Day song, "Now More Than Ever," was written by [[Marvin Hamlisch]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.afpnet.org/tier3_cd.cfm?folder_id=1625&content_item_id=13366 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2018-02-14 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051125094106/http://www.afpnet.org/tier3_cd.cfm?folder_id=1625&content_item_id=13366 |archivedate=November 25, 2005 |df= }}, National Philanthropy Day page at afpnet.org, retrieved 19 June 2017</ref><ref>{{cite song |author=Marvin Hamlisch |title=Now More Than Ever |year=1986 |url=http://www.afpnet.org/files/ContentDocuments/NPD%20Song.pdf}}, retrieved 19 June 2017</ref>
The day has been celebrated by AFP chapters across the US, including San Diego, California<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Sharp Mary Birch Celebrates 25 Years |date= June 5, 2017 |url=http://www.sandiegomagazine.com/Blogs/Monday-Morning-Good-News/Spring-2017/Sharp-Mary-Birch-Celebrates-25-Years/}} ''San Diego Magazine'', retrieved 19 June 2017</ref><ref>{{cite newspaper |title=National Philanthropy Day honors O.C. folks who give back in a big way |date= June 5, 2017 |url=http://www.ocregister.com/2016/09/19/national-philanthropy-day-honors-oc-folks-who-give-back-in-a-big-way/}} ''The Orange County Register'', retrieved 19 June 2017</ref>, Toledo, Ohio <ref>{{cite newspaper |title=Local philanthropists lauded |date= November 17, 2015 |url=http://www.toledoblade.com/BarbaraHendel/2016/11/17/Around-Town-Local-philanthropists-lauded-at-National-Philanthropy-Day-celebration-luncheon.html}} ''Toledo Blade'', retrieved 19 June 2017</ref>, Chattanooga, Tennessee<ref>{{cite newspaper |title=Civic Leader Tom Edd Wilson Dies Just After Leading Erlanger Children's Hospital Campaign |date= June 11, 2017 |url=http://www.chattanoogan.com/2017/6/11/349604/Civic-Leader-Tom-Edd-Wilson-Dies-Just.aspx}} ''The Chattanoogan'', retrieved 19 June 2017</ref>, Detroit, Michigan<ref>{{cite newspaper |title=8 honored for 2016 National Philanthropy Day awards |date= October 23, 2016 |url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20161023/NEWS/161029958/8-honored-for-2016-national-philanthropy-day-awards}} ''Crain's Detroit Business'', retrieved 19 June 2017</ref>.

Symbol ! Name ! Image ! References |- | [[National flag|Flag]] | [[Flag of the United States]] | [[File:Flag of the United States.svg|200px]] | 4 U.S.C. § 1 ("The [[flag of the United States]] shall be thirteen horizontal stripes, alternate red and white; and the union of the flag shall be forty-eight stars, white in a blue field."); § 2 ("On the admission of a new State into the Union one star shall be added to the union of the flag; and such addition shall take effect on the fourth day of July then next succeeding such admission."). |- | [[National seal|Seal]] | [[Great Seal of the United States]] | [[File:Great Seal of the United States (obverse).svg|150px]] (''obverse'')

{{multiple issues| {{news release|1=article|date=November 2014}} {{peacock|date=November 2014}} {{COI|date=November 2014}} }} {{Infobox recurring event | name = New Music Seminar | image = NMS_Logo_2012.jpg | caption = New Music Seminar Official Logo | frequency = Year-round events | venue = New Yorker Hotel and Various Live Music Venues in NYC | years_active = 20 | founded = 1980–1995, 2009–present | founder_name = [[Tom Silverman]], [[Mark Josephson]], [[Danny Heaps]], Scott Anderson | number = | location = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States]] | people = [[Tom Silverman]]: Founder & Executive Director | language = | website = {{URL|newmusicseminar.com}} }} The '''New Music Seminar''' (NMS) is a Music Conference and Festival held annually each June in [[New York City]]. The New Music Seminar originally ran from 1980 to 1995 and was relaunched in 2009. NMS features over 150 [[CEO]]s and other executives, presidents, and other leaders in the emerging music business along with over 100 artist performances. In 2012, NMS hosted the first New York Music Festival in collaboration with the [[New York City Mayor]]'s Office of Media & Entertainment declaration of the city’s first [[New York Music Week]]. The festival took place in 17 venues throughout [[Manhattan]] and [[Brooklyn]]. New Music Seminar 2015 took place June 21-23 in New York City. ==History== ===1980–95=== In June 1980, [[Tom Silverman]], [[Mark Josephson]], [[Danny Heaps]], and Scott Anderson brought 220 people together at a New York City rehearsal studio to discuss challenges in the music business. The event grew in subsequent years to act as a catalyst for change in it. The New Music Seminar added music showcases and a [[festival]], initially called "New York Nights" and later, "New Music Nights." These were held in various New York City clubs. At its peak, the first series of seminars attracted more than 8,000 participants from 35 countries. [[Haoui Montaug]] was panel director of the NMS at the time of his 1991 death.{{cite news|title=Haoui Montaug; Disco Doorman, 39|work=The New York Times|page=25|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/12/obituaries/haoui-montaug-disco-doorman-39.html}} Following his death, the NMS inaugurated the Haoui Montag New Music Awards in his honour.{{cite book|author=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|title=Billboard|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jg8EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA13|accessdate=9 June 2013|date=30 May 1992|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|pages=13–|issn=0006-2510}} ===2009=== In 2009, the New Music Seminar was relaunched by [[Tom Silverman]] and former New Music Seminar staffer [[Dave Lory]].[http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/content_display/industry/news/e3ida99bf36787f149a7c5d6345eccffc00/ NMS Returns 2009 Billboard] ====New York CIty==== The New Music Seminar returned as a one-day event to its hometown in the 2009 summer on July 21. It was an event that created the template for music conferences by combining business and shows.{{cn|date=March 2018}} Held at the [[New York University]] [[Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human Development|Steinhardt]]'s Skirball Center for the Performing Arts, the program consisted of a keynote, four educational sessions on how to combine new and old methods with technology for career success, and an artists' showcase. ====Chicago==== Following reviews from the New York City conference on July 21, the New Music Seminar went to Chicago for the first time on October 6 at the historic [[Park West (music venue)|Park West]].[http://www.hiphoppress.com/tag/new-music-seminar/ NMS Comes to Chicago 2009] On October 6 in Chicago, the reincarnated New Music Seminar kicked off with keynote address by [[Michael Spiegelman]], head of [[Yahoo! Music]], and was followed by four panel discussions: * Welcome to the Music Business; everything you know is wrong. Redefining Success. 1000 True Fans and the Fan Relationship Pyramid. * Expose Yourself: Marketing for the next music business; MySpace, Facebook and Twitter are not enough. * The Creative Process and radical Differentiation; Supercharge your music to rise above the noise floor and achieve success * The Live Show and Tour; How to Cut through the Glut and reach the Magic 300{{cite news|url=https://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/new-music-seminar/Event?oid=1209477|title=Best of Chicago: New Music Seminar|publisher=Chicago Reader|date=October 2009}} ===2010=== ====Los Angeles==== New Music Seminar came to [[L.A.]]’s [[Henry Fonda Theater]] on Feb 2 as a one-day music, networking and educational extravaganza for industry professionals seeking to learn and understand how to help artists “rise above the noise floor” in a shifting musical landscape.[http://www.kickmag.net/2010/01/the-new-music-seminar-hits-los-angeles-february-2nd-2010/ Kickmag New Music Seminar PR 2010] Featured players included: CMO [[Pepsi]], [[Kevin Lyman]], president/founder of [[Warp Tour]], [[Alexandra Patsavas]] of Chop Shop Music, [[Justin Tranter]], [[lead singer]] of [[Semi Precious Weapons]], [[Derek Sivers]], founder of [[CD Baby]] and [[Jason Bentley]], [[program director]] of [[KCRW]]. The full-day conference included four “movements” a.k.a. panels, live performances, the New Music Seminar “Artist on The Verge” contest winner performance and a great deal of networking both before, during and after the event. The conference featured Keynote address followed by four Movements: * 1st Movement: Welcome to the Music Business; Everything you know is wrong. The New Definition of Success. 1000 True Fans and the Fan Relationship Pyramid. * 2nd Movement: Get Arrested; Marketing Yourself in the New Music Business – MySpace, Facebook and Twitter are not enough. * 3rd Movement: The Creative Process and radical Differentiation; Supercharge your music to rise above the noise floor and achieve success. A virtual [[A&R]] meeting. * 4th Movement: The Live Show and Tour; How to Cut through the Glut and reach the Magic 300 Ticket Mark ====New York City==== New Music Seminar announced that it would no longer remain a one-day conference and expand into a multi-day event from July 19 to 21 in New York City. The two-day, three-night conference included a symphony of five "movements" (focused discussions) over the course of two days, 8 TED-style presentations from key industry leaders, 22 mentoring sessions, nightly musical performances and ongoing networking opportunities. This seminar address both the artists’ dilemma of breaking out from the ever-growing glut of music releases and the development of a new business model for a sustainable music business. NMS featured speakers included: Eric Garland (Big Champagne), Joe Kennedy ([[Pandora Music|Pandora]]), Mike Doernberg ([[Reverbnation]]), Courtney Holt ([[Myspace|Myspace Music]]), David Goodman ([[CBS Interactive]]), [[Little Steven]] ([[Underground Garage]] and the [[E Street Band]]), [[Ariel Hyatt]] (Ariel PR), Corey Denis (Not Shocking), Linda Lorence ([[SESAC]]), Jay Frank (CMT), Gwen Lipsky (Sound Thinking), Tom Jackson (onstagesuccess.com), [[Martin Atkins]] (Tour: Smart), John Simson (Soundexchange), Corrie Christopher (APA), Chris Vinson ([[Bandzoogle]]), and Tony Van Veen (Discmakers). The Artist Movement “conducted” by [[Margaret Cho]] featured star artists discussing how they got their break and tips on how to apply what worked for them. ===2011–13=== After a sold-out event in New York City on July 19–21, 2010, New Music Seminar returned to Los Angeles one day after the Grammys, with its 3-day event from February 14 through 16th, 2011, at the Sheraton Universal Hotel. The kickoff red carpet event, The After Grammy Jammy (the NMS Opening Night Party), was held at The Music Box in Hollywood on Monday night, February 14 with the “Artist on the Verge Finals”, which selects one artist who will walk away with over $50K in promotion and marketing, Tuesday, February 15 at The Roxy. The two-day, three-night conference included a symphony of five "movements" (focused discussions) over the course of two days, 12–18 minute Intensives (presentations) from key industry leaders, 22 mentoring sessions, daily and nightly musical performances, Summit Meetings and workshops on Rock, Hip Hop, Producers and Songwriting along with ongoing networking opportunities throughout. On June 17–19, 2012, the New Music Seminar explored the exciting future of the music business with the [[SoundExchange]] Digital Broadcasting Summit and the [[Broadcast Music, Inc.|BMI]] Creative Conclave; which took place at Webster Hall in New York City. The creative community and their label partners met the digital broadcasters, music bloggers, music technologists and all of the new music exposure and monetization players. Clear Channel CEO, Bob Pittman and [[Sean Parker]]http://www.berkleegroove.com/2012/07/17/the-best-of-the-best-top-insight-from-the-2012-new-music-seminar/ were the keynote speakers and shared their vision for the future. Many sectors of the evolving new music business convened to discuss their perspectives for the exciting new future for the music business. In 2013, the New Music Seminar, along with the [[SoundExchange]] Digital Broadcasting Summit, moved to the iconic [[New Yorker Hotel]] and held its opening night party at [[Webster Hall]]. 2013 marked a growth in international relationships spearheaded by the newly appointed General Manager, Peter Schwinge. Music showcases from [[France]], [[Spain]], and [[Sweden]] – an International Movement conducted by [[MIDEM]], and an uptick in international sponsors and delegates enhanced the discussion throughout the global music community.
A new addition, to the benefit of artists, was the Music Xray A&R Listening and Critique room where artists had the opportunity to have their music listened to, and critiqued by reps from [[Atlantic Records]], [[Republic Records]], [[RCA Records]], [[Virgin Records]], Label Recruit, LOCAL VIBES, [[Glassnote Records]], [[Razor & Tie]], [[Robbins Entertainment]], [[Island Def Jam]], and [[Columbia Records]]. There was a 2015 event.https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/6436548/new-music-seminar-set-for-june-in-nyc ==Similar events== Since the New Music Seminar's inception, many important music conferences worldwide have been formed, including [[SXSW]], [[Winter Music Conference]], [[In the City (festival)|In the City]], [[CMJ]] and [[Canadian Music Week]]. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Music conferences]] [[Category:Music festivals in New York City]]

{{Translation_WIP|同音文章|Chinese|zh}}
A '''one-syllable article''' ({{zh|c=同音文章|p=Tóngyīn wénzhāng}}) is a type of [[constrained writing]] found in [[Chinese literature]]. It takes advantage of the large number of [[Chinese language#Homophones|homophones in the Chinese language]], particularly when writing in [[Classical Chinese]] due to historic sound changes. While the [[Chinese character|characters]] used in a one-syllable article have many different meanings, they are all pronounced as the same syllable, although not with the same [[tone (linguistics)|tone]]. Therefore, a one-syllable article is comprehensible in writing but becomes an incomprehensible [[tongue twister]] when read aloud, especially in [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin Chinese]] pronunciation. In other regional pronunciations not all syllables may sound alike.
==Notable examples== <!--Someone who is more competent in Classical Chinese should check these English translations and fix any issues that are present, as they might not be as good as they should be.--> <!--we should clarify the part about reading them aloud and reading. Can one comprehend a spoken form?--> *[[Lion-Eating Poet in the Stone Den]] ({{zh|s=施氏食狮史|t=施氏食獅史|p=Shī Shì shí shī shǐ}}), by [[Yuen Ren Chao]] *{{Interlanguage link multi|The nephew who treats hemorrhoids|zh|3=侄治痔}} ({{zh|c=侄治痔|p=zhí zhì zhì}}), by He Yuanwai *{{Interlanguage link multi|The legendary archer's descendant: Yi|wikisource:zh|3=羿裔熠}} ({{zh|c=羿裔熠|p=yì yì yì}}) *{{Interlanguage link multi|Suspecting the physician of losing gold|wikisource:zh|3=遗镒疑医}} ({{zh|s=遗镒疑医|t=遺鎰疑醫|p=yí yì yí yī}}) *{{Interlanguage link multi|Auntie Yi's pancreatic cure|wikisource:zh|3=易姨医胰}} ({{zh|s=易姨医胰|t=易姨醫胰|p=yì yí yī yí}}) *{{Interlanguage link multi|Yu Yu who intends fishing|wikisource:zh|3=于瑜欲渔}} ({{zh|s=于瑜欲渔|t=于瑜欲漁|p=yú yú yù yú}}) *{{Interlanguage link multi|Xi who plays with rhinoceros|wikisource:zh|3=熙戏犀}} ({{zh|s=熙戏犀|t=熙戲犀|p=xī xì xī}}) *{{Interlanguage link multi|Narration on starving chickens' assembly at a rift|wikisource:zh|3=饥鸡集矶记}} ({{zh|s=饥鸡集矶记|t=飢雞集磯記|p=jī jī jí jī jì}}) <!--*{{ill|wikisource:zh|Narration on Lady Ji's assault against chickens|季姬击鸡记}} ({{zh|s=季姬击鸡记|t=季姬擊雞記|p=jì jī jí jī jì}})-->
